Package com.teksystems.salestaxexercise

Interface TaxableItem

All Superinterfaces:
Taxable
All Known Implementing Classes:
TaxableItemImpl
public interface TaxableItem
extends Taxable
Interface for a specific product or service which is taxable. As opposed to the more generic Taxable interface which can apply to collections of taxable items as well.
Author:
Andrew

  • Method Summary

    Modifier and Type Method Description
    void addTaxAmount​(Tax tax, org.joda.money.Money amount)
    Add a specific tax and the amount of that tax for this specific item.
    void addTaxAmounts​(java.util.LinkedHashMap<Tax,​org.joda.money.Money> taxAmounts)
    Add an ordered set of taxes and amounts.
    SellableItem getSellableItem()
    Get the sellable item associated with this taxable item.

    Methods inherited from interface com.teksystems.salestaxexercise.Taxable

    getTaxAmounts, getTotalPriceWithTax, getTotalTax

  • Method Details

    • getSellableItem

      SellableItem getSellableItem()
      Get the sellable item associated with this taxable item. This interface does not extend SellableItem, but instead include this getter for an underlying SellableItem. Chose to implement this using composition, rather than inheritance, as the Liskov substitution principle could not necessarily be maintained in all instances if inheritance was used. Something that's true about a priced item in general is not guaranteed to always be true once the taxes for a specific tax jurisdiction are added to that item.
      Returns:
      The SellableItem object to which this taxable item adds taxes.

    • addTaxAmount

      void addTaxAmount​(Tax tax, org.joda.money.Money amount)
      Add a specific tax and the amount of that tax for this specific item. This is here, and not in the more generic Taxable interface like the corresponding getter Taxable.getTaxAmounts(), because you should not be able to directly add a tax amount to a taxable collection - the tax amounts for a collection of taxable items should be the sum of the tax amounts for the taxable items inside that collection.
      Parameters:
      tax - the tax that is being applied to the item
      amount - the amount of that tax for this item

    • addTaxAmounts

      void addTaxAmounts​(java.util.LinkedHashMap<Tax,​org.joda.money.Money> taxAmounts)
      Add an ordered set of taxes and amounts. The SOLID design principle that interfaces should wherever possible depend on other interfaces, not concrete classes, would suggest this method should take a Map as its parameter, not a LinkedHashMap. However, because some taxes may be assessed on top of other taxes, maintaining the order of taxes may be very important in many implementations. I decided the benefits of forcing every implementer to implement with a structure that maintains order outweighed the potential loss in flexibility.
      Parameters:
      taxAmounts - an ordered map of taxes and their respective amounts for this taxable item
